TopicTitle: Do solar panels still radiate enough heat for NERVs?

Articles.Content: I notice that NERVs generate a lot less heat than they used to. Does this mean that solar panels are a good enough solution to radiate the heat?
In the later versions of KSP I have never really needed any extra cooling for the NERV engine, even in clusters. They heat up, but never enough to cause any problems.

Unless you're using huge clusters on really long burns, I wouldn't expect trouble. I still put the smaller deployable heat unit on my large interplanetary craft, but I could probably get by without them.
Do the solar panels actually function as radiators, or is that just obsolete flavor text?

Everything functions as a passive radiator. And I suspect that the radiative power does go with the measured surface area.

But as said above -- NERVs still get hot, and still glow cherry red if you burn them for 10 minutes, and transfer heat to nearby not-so-heat-resistant parts -- but under most circumstances you won't get anywhere near a severe overheating situation. Even with no special cooling equipment.

The panels do seem to radiate some heat, but in my experience a burn longer than 5 minutes or so can overheat a single NERV.

note that this is heavily dependent on other factors, like how close you are to the sun, if you're on the night side of a body, etc.

But i do know that I have overheated single nervs with xl panels on moho during suicide burns.
